Award.AwardTitle: III: Medium: Machine Learning with Humans in the Loop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Machine learning is increasingly used in systems common in daily life -- from search engines to online education to smart homes. Through interactions with their users, these systems learn about the world to improve efficiency and performance. Building effective and robust Human-Interactive Learning (HIL) systems, however, requires a framework that simultaneously integrates models of human behavior with the design of machine learning algorithms, because user data is only an indirect mapping, mediated through the human decision-making process, of the knowledge the system aims to elicit. This project takes an interdisciplinary approach to developing effective techniques to design human-interactive learning systems.

This project explores how humans provide data and how learning algorithms use this data in an integrated framework that encompasses three aspects. First, the project develops models of the user decision process, formalizing how observable user actions map to the underlying knowledge the system aims to acquire. Second, these models inform the design of the interface that connects the user and the learning algorithm to suitably trade off the quantity and quality of the data acquired. Third, the user model and interface motivate new machine learning settings and algorithms to maximize learning efficiency. By developing an integrated framework for the three interconnected components for building Human Interactive Learning Systems -- human decision models, information-elicitation interfaces, and learning algorithms -- this project will impact future designs of widely-used systems such as non-web information search, recommendation, and online education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Machine learning is a central component in systems increasingly common in daily life -- from search engines to online education to smart homes. Through interactions with their users, these systems learn about the world to improve efficiency and performance. Building effective and robust Human-Interactive Learning (HIL) systems, however, requires an integrated framework that simultaneously integrates models of human behavior with the design of machine learning algorithms, because user data is only an indirect mapping, mediated through the human decision-making process, of the knowledge the system aims to elicit. Following this insight, the project developed an understanding of how humans provide data and how learning algorithms use this data in an integrated framework that encompasses three aspects.

First, the project developed models of the user's decision process, formalizing how observable user actions map to the underlying knowledge the system aims to acquire. In particular, this led to new models of how users interact with search and recommendation systems that present rankings, and how relevance and exposure interact to form the feedback signal. Making connections to methods from causal inference and missing data analysis, the project developed propensity models that allow unbiased estimation of ranking performance even though the user feedback is biased by the ranking that was displayed. In particular, these models can correct for the fact that highly ranked items receive more exposure and thus have a better chance of being discovered. A core result of the project is that these models now provide a sound statistical basis for unbiased offline evaluation of ranking systems.

Second, the project developed new learning-to-rank methods that build upon these unbiased offline estimators of ranking performance. In particular, the project developed machine learning methods that can learn unbiased ranking policies despite the biases inherent in the feedback that users provide through their actions. These methods provide a rigorous approach for learning from such data without the need for interactive experimentation as required by online learning methods. 

Finally, the project explored not only how better machine learning methods can lead to better ranking quality, but also how to design the interface that connects the user and the learning algorithm. In particular, the project showed that design interventions in the interface can trade off the quantity of data that is acquired, the quality of the data, and the cost on the user experience that this may impose. In particular, it identified how transparency can lead to a better user experience, and how interface features like shortlists can decrease cognitive load on the user. Importantly, these improvements of the immediate user experience do not come at a cost of long-term usefulness of the system, since they simultaneously improve data quality and data quantity respectively.

In summary, by integrating these three interconnected components for building Human Interactive Learning Systems -- human decision models, learning algorithms, and information-elicitation interfaces -- this project had impact on the design of a range of widely-used systems. In addition to being readily adopted in a number of industrial applications, the techniques developed in this project contributed to the ArXiv Full-Text Search, the design of the Localify! music recommendation system, and the recommender system employed by the KDD 2020 Conference.
